description: Comprehensive Trigonometry concepts covering ratios, identities, and applications

definition.text: Trigonometric ratios relate the angles and sides of a right triangle. For an angle Î¸ in a right triangle: sine = opposite/hypotenuse, cosine = adjacent/hypotenuse, tangent = opposite/adjacent. These ratios extend to all angles using the unit circle.

keyFormulas.name: Sine
keyFormulas.meaning: Ratio of opposite side to hypotenuse

keyFormulas.name: Cosine
keyFormulas.meaning: Ratio of adjacent side to hypotenuse

keyFormulas.name: Tangent
keyFormulas.formula: tan Î¸ = opposite / adjacent = sin Î¸ / cos Î¸
keyFormulas.meaning: Ratio of opposite to adjacent side

keyFormulas.name: Cosecant
keyFormulas.formula: csc Î¸ = 1 / sin Î¸ = hypotenuse / opposite

keyFormulas.name: Secant
keyFormulas.formula: sec Î¸ = 1 / cos Î¸ = hypotenuse / adjacent

keyFormulas.name: Cotangent
keyFormulas.formula: cot Î¸ = 1 / tan Î¸ = adjacent / opposite

definition.text: The unit circle is a circle with radius 1 centered at the origin. For any angle Î¸ measured from the positive x-axis, the point on the unit circle is (cos Î¸, sin Î¸). This extends trig functions to all real numbers.

definition.text: Trigonometric identities are equations involving trig functions that are true for all valid values of the variables. These identities are essential for simplifying expressions and solving equations.

keyFormulas.name: Sum Formula - Sine
keyFormulas.formula: sin(A + B) = sin A cos B + cos A sin B

keyFormulas.name: Sum Formula - Cosine
keyFormulas.formula: cos(A + B) = cos A cos B - sin A sin B

examples.question: Simplify: sinÂ²Î¸ + sinÂ²Î¸Â·tanÂ²Î¸
Find the exact value of sin 75Â°

steps.explanation: sin(A+B) = sin A cos B + cos A sin B

proof: Consider a right triangle with angle Î¸
Let opposite = a, adjacent = b, hypotenuse = c
sin Î¸ = a/c, cos Î¸ = b/c
By Pythagorean theorem: aÂ² + bÂ² = cÂ²

definition.text: The Law of Sines states that in any triangle, the ratio of a side length to the sine of its opposite angle is constant. This allows solving triangles when given two angles and a side (AAS, ASA) or two sides and an opposite angle (SSA).

keyFormulas.name: Law of Sines
keyFormulas.formula: a/sin A = b/sin B = c/sin C
keyFormulas.meaning: Ratio of side to sine of opposite angle is constant

keyFormulas.name: Alternative Form
keyFormulas.formula: sin A/a = sin B/b = sin C/c

examples.question: In triangle ABC, A = 40Â°, B = 60Â°, and a = 8. Find b.

definition.text: The Law of Cosines generalizes the Pythagorean theorem to all triangles. It relates the square of one side to the squares of the other two sides and the cosine of their included angle. Useful for SAS and SSS cases.

keyFormulas.name: Law of Cosines
keyFormulas.meaning: Find side opposite to known angle

keyFormulas.name: Angle Form
keyFormulas.meaning: Find angle when all sides known

examples.question: In triangle ABC, a = 7, b = 8, and C = 60Â°. Find c.

steps.explanation: Use formula for side opposite known angle

examples.verification: When C = 90Â°, reduces to Pythagorean theorem

proof: Law of Cosines: cÂ² = aÂ² + bÂ² - 2ab cos C
Becomes: cÂ² = aÂ² + bÂ² - 2ab(0) = aÂ² + bÂ²
This is exactly the Pythagorean theorem!
Hence, Law of Cosines generalizes Pythagoras â–¡

definition.text: Inverse trigonometric functions find the angle when given a ratio. sinâ»Â¹(x) (or arcsin x) returns the angle whose sine is x. These functions have restricted ranges to ensure they're true inverses.

definition.text: Trigonometry is applied extensively in real-world problems involving angles and distances. Common applications include height and distance problems, navigation, surveying, physics (waves, projectiles), and engineering.

definition.text: Radians are an alternative to degrees for measuring angles. One radian is the angle where arc length equals radius. A full circle is 2Ï€ radians. Radians are essential for calculus and physics.

definition.text: Solving trigonometric equations means finding all angles that satisfy the equation. Since trig functions are periodic, there are usually infinitely many solutions, often expressed using general solutions.

keyFormulas.name: General Solution for sin x = a
keyFormulas.formula: x = sinâ»Â¹(a) + 2Ï€n or x = Ï€ - sinâ»Â¹(a) + 2Ï€n
